item.title: Joe Gilbert on "The human side of content management?"
item.dc:creator: Joe Gilbert
item.description:
Hi Korey,

It sounds like in part you're interested in the field we call "Content Strategy". Here are some well-regarded books on the topic:

  • Content Strategy at Work by Margot Bloomstein
  • Content Strategy for the Web by Kristina Halvorson
  • The Elements of Content Strategy by Erin Kissane

The CMS Myth blog might be another good starting point for you.

item.description: I'm not sure if this is exactly what you're looking for, but George Williams wrote a ProfHacker article last year about how we manage the writing of that blog. It doesn't cover everything you're looking for, but it hits a lot of it.

item.title: Korey Jackson on "The human side of content management?"
item.dc:creator: Korey Jackson
item.description:
I'm helping a local campus division start a community website and wondering if anyone has good models, project plans, best practices, etc. for content management...specifically from the "how-do-I-make-sure-this-About-page-stays-current-or-this-guest-blog-post-is-timely-and-postworthy" side of things.

In other words: what kind of management structure works best for the creation, submission, vetting, user-account admin'ing, content-wrangling aspect of web development?

Thanks!
